marketNews.title: Car Sales in Feb 2024 Remain Weak; ASII Market Share Rises
marketNews.content: Wholesale car sales in Indonesia in February 2024 were recorded at 70,656 units, growing +1.5% MoM, but down -18.8% YoY. The monthly growth was mainly supported by increased sales of car brands under the umbrella of Astra International (ASII), such as Toyota and Daihatsu. Meanwhile, other brands like Wuling (-44.9% MoM), Hyundai (-19.2% MoM), Suzuki (-18.7% MoM), Mitsubishi (-8.4% MoM) experienced a decline. ASII itself recorded wholesale sales of 41,240 units in February 2024, up +8.6% MoM, but down -11.4% YoY annually. Results that were relatively better than the industry average caused ASII's market share to increase to 58.4% in February 2024 (vs. January 2024: 54.6%, February 2023: 53.5%). Cumulatively over 2M24, wholesale car sales in Indonesia only reached 140,275 units, down -22.6% YoY. All brands - except Wuling - experienced a sales decline in 2M24. These results only met 12.7% of the 2024 target set by Gaikindo at 1.1 million units. For comparison, the realization for 2M22 and 2M23 met 15.8% and 18% respectively of the total sales in those years. Marketing Director of PT Toyota-Astra Motor (TAM), Anton Jimmi Suwandy, stated that the weakening car sales at the beginning of 2024 were suppressed by purchase deferrals from retail and business (fleet) consumers approaching the election moment. Furthermore, Bisnis reported that the decline in car sales at the beginning of 2024 was also triggered by the government's delay in extending the government-borne VAT incentive for electric vehicles. For information, electric car sales contributed 3.4% to wholesale car sales in 4Q23. Key Takeaway: Although sales in the coming months have the potential to recover as the election concludes and electric car sales increase, we assess that there is still a risk that the 2024 target of 1.1 million units set by Gaikindo will not be met. Meanwhile, the relatively better sales of ASII were responded to positively by the market, with the company's share price rising +2.43% to 5,275 rupiah per share on Thursday (14/3). Currently, ASII is trading at a valuation of 7.0x 1-Year Forward P/E, equivalent to the valuation during the Covid-19 pandemic. Additionally, ASII also plans to propose a final dividend of 421 rupiah per share, which indicates a final dividend yield of 8% as of Thursday (14/3).

marketNews.title: BBCA Distributes Final Dividend with Indication Yield of 2.2%
marketNews.content: BBCA: Shareholders of Bank Central Asia approved the distribution of a final dividend of 28 trillion rupiah or 227.5 rupiah per share. The cum-dividend date and payment date have not yet been announced. Referring to BBCA's stock price at the stock market close on Thursday (14/3) at 10,325 rupiah per share, the indicative final dividend yield is 2.2%. Previously, BBCA had also distributed an interim dividend of 5.2 trillion rupiah or 42.5 rupiah per share in December 2023. Thus, BBCA's total dividend payout ratio for the 2023 fiscal year is 68.4%. INCO: Vale Indonesia plans to hold a rights issue of up to ~603.5 million new shares, with a dilution effect of up to 5.73%. The exercise price and ratio have not been announced. This corporate action is part of fulfilling INCO's share divestment obligation to MIND ID. The funds obtained from the rights issue are intended for capital expenditure and working capital. This plan will be discussed at the EGM on April 19, 2024. DGNS: Diagnos Laboratorium Utama plans to hold a rights issue of up to 921 million (73.7%) new shares, with a dilution effect of up to 42%. The exercise price is set at 505 rupiah per share, with the majority of the funds obtained intended for the acquisition of 98% of the shares of Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. through an inbreng scheme and share purchases. Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. is the owner of PT Asa Ren Global Nusantara, a company in the field of trading laboratory equipment, pharmaceutical equipment, and human medical devices. DGNS's controller, Bundamedik (BMHS), will transfer a portion of its rights to the shareholders of Asa Ren Pte. Ltd. This plan will be discussed at the EGM on April 19, 2024. DOID: Delta Dunia Makmur recorded a net profit of 36 million US dollars (+26% YoY) in 2023, supported by revenue growth of +18% YoY to 1.8 billion US dollars. From an operational perspective, overburden removal grew +14% YoY, while production volume increased at mines in Indonesia (+10% YoY) and Australia (+28% YoY). In 4Q23, DOID booked revenue of 470 million US dollars (-7% QoQ), with a net profit of 16.4 million US dollars (-3% QoQ). ENRG: Investor Relations Advisor for Energi Mega Persada, Herwin W. Hidayat, stated that the company targets gas and oil production growth of around +10-15% YoY in 2024. In 2023, the company recorded an average daily production of 5,700 barrels of oil per day (BOPD) and 165 million cubic feet of gas per day (MMSCFD). ENRG allocates capex of 150 million US dollars in 2024, which is intended for development drilling costs, construction of gas pipelines, and additional construction of production facilities. ACST: Acset Indonusa plans to expand its business activities into civil mining construction and other mining support and excavation activities. ACST management stated that this business expansion is based on the continuously increasing mining industry. Additionally, ACST has access to potential mining construction projects through its parent company, United Tractors (UNTR). With the addition of this business line, ACST's asset value is projected to grow +10.46% in 2024-2028 to 1.9 trillion rupiah. IMPC: The controller of Impack Pratama Industri, PT Tunggal Jaya Investama, sold 550.5 million IMPC shares at a price of 390 rupiah per share on March 7, 2024. The total transaction value reached 215 billion rupiah. This transaction was intended to increase the free float share amount. After this transaction, the ownership of PT Tunggal Jaya Investama in IMPC decreased from 43.91% to 42.89%.

marketNews.title: Meat Import Realization Delayed Due to Budget and Permit Issues; Frozen Beef Stock Only 7,500-8,000 Tons
marketNews.content: ID Food CEO, Frans Marganda, stated that the company has not yet realized the assignment to import 20,000 tons of beef from Brazil this year due to budget issues and delayed import permits. Meanwhile, Secretary General of the Indonesian Meat Importers Association (Aspidi), Suhandri, stated that current frozen beef stock at importers is only around 7,500-8,000 tons. This amount is considered insufficient for the needs during Eid al-Fitr, which requires at least 50,000 tons to curb price surges.

marketNews.title: BP Tapera to Review 35-Year Fixed-Rate Mortgage Scheme Involving SMF and BTN
marketNews.content: Commissioner of the Public Housing Savings Management Agency (BP Tapera), Heru Pudyo Nugroho, stated that they will review the fixed-interest rate mortgage scheme with a tenor of 35 years. The review of this discourse will involve relevant stakeholders, such as PT Sarana Multigriya Finansial (SMF) and Bank Tabungan Negara (BBTN).

marketNews.title: DPR Commission VII Requests Review of 2030 Oil Lifting Target of 1 Million Barrels Per Day as Unrealistic
marketNews.content: Commission VII of the DPR requested that the oil lifting target from SKK Migas of 1 million barrels per day in 2030 be reviewed because it is deemed unrealistic. In 2023, the realization of oil lifting only reached 605,500 barrels per day, far below the 2023 State Budget target of 660,000 barrels per day and the 2023 Work Plan and Budget (WP&B) target of 621,000 barrels per day. Meanwhile, the Head of SKK Migas, Dwi Soetjipto, stated that the target would likely be delayed by 2-3 years.

marketNews.title: Brent Crude Futures Strengthened +2.6% Driven by Lower Crude Inventory Draw in the US
marketNews.content: The price of Brent crude futures strengthened +2.6% to 84.03 US dollars per barrel on Wednesday (13/3). The price strengthening occurred following an announcement from the US energy agency, Energy Information Administration (EIA), which reported that the crude oil inventory withdrawal for the period ending March 8, 2024, reached 1.5 million barrels, exceeding the consensus expectation of 1.3 million barrels. Additionally, EIA also noted that the gasoline withdrawal reached 5.7 million barrels, far exceeding the consensus estimate of 1.9 million barrels.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Notes Retail Sales Grew +1.1% YoY in January 2024, Forecasts +3.6% YoY Growth in February 2024
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia recorded that retail sales in Indonesia increased +1.1% YoY in January 2024 (vs. Dec 2023: +0.2% YoY). This realization marks consecutive annual growth for the last 8 months. On a monthly basis, retail sales contracted by -3.5% MoM, in line with the normalization of public demand after the end of Christmas and New Year holidays and unfavorable weather conditions. Bank Indonesia forecasts that retail sales in February 2024 will grow +3.6% YoY, but will still contract MoM.

marketNews.title: OJK Will Soon Issue Regulation on Transparency of Lending Base Rate (SBDK) for Conventional Commercial Banks
marketNews.content: Head of Banking Supervision at OJK, Dian Ediana Rae, stated that they will soon issue regulations regarding the transparency of the lending base rate (SBDK) for conventional commercial banks. The principles to be regulated in this regulation include the basic components forming the interest rate. Later, banks will also be required to submit SBDK reports covering overhead costs and profit margins.

marketNews.title: Government Proposes Jakarta Agglomeration Area to be Led by Vice President in the Jakarta Special Region Bill (RUU DKJ)
marketNews.content: Minister of Home Affairs, Tito Karnavian, stated that the government proposes that the governance of the Jakarta agglomeration area be placed under the auspices of the Vice President. The Jakarta agglomeration governance will be regulated in the Jakarta Special Region Bill (RUU DKJ).

marketNews.title: Soekarno-Hatta Customs Limits the Number of Imported Goods Passengers Can Bring
marketNews.content: Customs at Soekarno-Hatta restricted the quantity of imported goods passengers can carry. Commodities with restricted carrying amounts include shoes, footwear, bags, textile goods, electronic devices, mobile phones, headsets, and tablet computers. This restriction is effective starting March 10, 2024, and is based on Trade Ministerial Regulation No. 36 of 2023. Head of Soekarno-Hatta Customs Office, Gatot Sugeng Wibowo, stated that the enforcement of this Ministerial Regulation will impact import activities via passenger carry-on baggage.
